Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

How I Handle Logging in High-Load .NET Payment SystemsIn the world of payment systems, logging is not just about writing to a file. itâ€™s a key part of auditing, debugging, and even compliance.Hereâ€™s my go to approach for handling logging in high-load .NET environments:1-Use structured logging (with Serilog + Elasticsearch + Kibana)2-Keep logging async and non-blocking3-Separate logs by correlation ID (especially for ISO8583 transactions)4-Donâ€™t log sensitive data (mask PANs, CVVs, etc.)5-Always log both success and failure flowsYour logs should tell a story. a transaction's journey from request to response.Curious to hear how youâ€™re handling logging in your .NET projects.Letâ€™s share ideas and build better systems together.hashtag#dotnet hashtag#logging hashtag#paymentsystems hashtag#softwarearchitecture hashtag#serilog hashtag#iso8583 hashtag#fintech hashtag#backendengineering hashtag#csharp

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

11 remote jobs pay $80/hr.No Resume No Experience required.I've tested dozens of platforms to curate this list.Bookmark before it's taken down:1. TextBroker:TextBroker provides freelance writing opportunities with compensation rates ranging from 1.4-5 cents per word.2. Free Cash:Free Cash offers flexible opportunities for earning extra income by completing simple tasks online.3. Gengo:Gengo offers translation jobs with flexible schedules. Pay ranges from $17 to $33/hour.4. TaskRabbit:TaskRabbit provides a variety of local services, as well as some remote options like computer support and graphic design.5. UserTesting:UserTesting pays you to test websites and apps. Earn $4-$120 per test, with durations ranging from 5 minutes to live interviews.6. Arise:Arise provides remote customer service opportunities where you can work as an independent contractor.7. Clickworker:Clickworker offers microtasks with customizable scheduling. Pay varies greatly by task, potentially ranging from $10 to $50+/hour.8. Gaggle:Gaggle hires content reviewers to monitor online student activities and promote kid safety. Pay ranges from $20 to $25/hour.9. Preply:Preply is an online tutoring platform offering opportunities in over 100 subjects. Set your own rates, with potential earnings exceeding $40/hour.10. Transcription Hub:Transcription Hub provides flexible transcription jobs, allowing you to choose your own schedule.11. Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Pay ranges from $17 to $33/hour.4. TaskRabbit:TaskRabbit provides a variety of local services, as well as some remote options like computer support and graphic design.5. Arise:Arise provides remote customer service opportunities where you can work as an independent contractor.7. Clickworker:Clickworker offers microtasks with customizable scheduling. Pay varies greatly by task, potentially ranging from $10 to $50+/hour.8. Gaggle:Gaggle hires content reviewers to monitor online student activities and promote kid safety. Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest

Ever used AsNoTracking() in EF Core? It can be the difference between a slow API and a fast one ğŸš€ğŸ§  What is AsNoTracking()?By default, when you query entities using Entity Framework Core, the DbContext tracks those entities so it can detect changes and persist them later with SaveChanges().But what if you're just reading data? ğŸ¤” You donâ€™t need tracking â€” and that's where AsNoTracking() comes in.âœ… Why should you use it? ğŸ”¹ Improves read performance. ğŸ”¹ Reduces memory usage. ğŸ”¹ Avoids the overhead of the change tracker. ğŸ”¹ Perfect for GET endpoints, reports, dashboards, etc.âš ï¸ When NOT to use AsNoTracking()? â¡ï¸ When you plan to modify and save those entities. â¡ï¸ When you need complex relationship tracking or entity change detection.ğŸ“Œ Pro Tip: If you're following a CQRS pattern, consider using AsNoTracking() by default for all queries, and enable tracking only for commands (create/update/delete operations).ğŸ’¬ Do you already use AsNoTracking() in your repositories? Do you separate queries and commands in your architecture?hashtag#dotnet hashtag#EntityFrameworkCore hashtag#AsNoTracking hashtag#Performance hashtag#CleanArchitecture hashtag#csharp hashtag#backend hashtag#apirest
